introduction.p:
Intensity in a wave is average energy flow per unit time per unit cross-sectional area. Energy per unit time is power, therefore, we write intensity as average power P_\text{av} divided by cross-secional area A_\perp.
I = \frac{P_\text{av}}{A_\perp}.
For a dislacement plane wave \psi(x,t) = D_0 \sin(k x - \omega t) flowing in a medium of density \rho, the intensity turns out to be
I = \frac{1}{2}\rho \frac{\omega^3}{k} D_0^2.
You could also write this in terms of the amplitude of the corresponding pressure wave by using P_0 =k B D_0, where B is the bulk modulus. With v=\omega/k, the wave speed, we will get the following for intensity in this case.
I = \frac{1}{2}\frac{\rho}{B^2} v^3 P_0^2.
This can be further simplified by noting that wave speed depends on the properties of the media by
v = \sqrt{\frac{B}{\rho}}.
Therefore, intensity in terms of the pressure wave amplitude will be
I = \frac{1}{2 \rho v} P_0^2.
The unit of intensity is \text{W/m}^2. When we hear sound, the loudness of the sound is primarily associated with the intensity, but other factors also impact our perception of loudness of the sound. We can say that intensity is an objective measure of energy flow in a wave and loudness is a subjective measure.
Often we are interested in comparing intensity of some sound with respect to another sound. This is done by defining another measure of intensity, called bel, which I will describe next.

subsection.title: Decibels and Sound Level
subsection.p:
The intensity of sound that a human can hear has a very wide range, from approximately 10^{-12}\text{ W/m}^2 to 1\text{ W/m}^2. In properties that have such wide range of interest, it is often the practice to introduce logarithmic scale. In the case of sound, the logarithm scale called decibel which uses base-10 log. Since the argument of log has to be dimensionless, we define the unit of \text{bel} by the log of a ratio of intensity I to a reference intensity I_0.
\text{Intensity in bel} = \log_{10}\, \frac{I}{I_0}.
A more common unit is decibel. You may recall that a deci-something is \frac{1}{10} of that thing. When we express the intensity in decibels, we call it the level of sound relative to the reference. We denote the level by the Greek letter \beta (beta) and the unit by dB.
\beta (\text{in dB}) = 10\ \log_{10}\, \frac{I}{I_0}.
Of course, given dB level \beta, we can get intensity by inverting this.
I = I_0\times 10^{\beta/10}.
Most commonly, the reference intensity is taken to be the lowest threshold of The reference intensity for sound wave is 10^{-12}\text{ W/m}^2, approximately the threshold of normal human hearing at 1000\text{ Hz} of frequency.
I_0 = 10^{-12}\text{ W/m}^2.
Thus, if the intensity of some sound is 1000-times the reference, then it will have a decibel of 30. Here is how:
\beta (\text{in dB}) = 10\ \log_{10}\, 10^3 = 10\times 3 = 30.
Log base 10 picks out the power of 10. Therefore, log base 10 of 1000 is just 3. The range of intensity for human hearing amounts to a range of 0 to 120\text{ dB}. A useful information to remember is that a 3\text{-dB} drop in intensity corresonds to intensity becoming half as much since we have
10\ \log_{10}\, \frac{1}{2} \approx - 3.

Since intensity of a wave is proportional to the square of the amplitude of the wave, we can express sound level in terms of amplitude as well. Let A and A_0 be the amplitudes of the test wave and the reference wave respectively, i.e.,
I = a A^2,\ \ \ \text{and}\ \ \ I_0 = a A_0^2,
where a is some common factor which will cancel out in the ratio. this gives sound level \beta in \text{dB} to be
\beta (\text{in dB}) = 20\ \log_{10}\, \frac{A}{A_0}.
Beware of the change in multicaptive factor to the log. This 20 and 10 is a source of common confusion.
High decibel level sound can cause hearing loss and injury. Centers for Disease Control (CDC) has noise chart in CDC-hearing-table to help you avoid hearing injuries.

subsection.title: Perception of Sound Level
subsection.p: If we hear a sound with intensity at 20\text{ dB} and the sound of same frequency at 40\text{ dB}, we can tell that the sound at 40\text{ dB} is louder. But if you were to play two sounds at the same intensity of 20\text{ dB}, but one of frequency 1000\text{ Hz}, and another of frequency 100\text{ Hz}, you would say that the 100\text{ Hz} sound is louder even though the two sounds had the same intensity.

Our perception of sound level does not purely depend on the intensity of sound. It also depends on the frequency. I have already pointed out that we can hear only those sound that are in the audible range, which extends from 20\text{ Hz} to about 20\text{ kHz}. Between, these two frequencies, our perception of loudness of sound varies with frequency as shown in , where the contours are labeled with the decibel of same loudness but of frequency 1000\text{ Hz}. The labeled \text{dB} values are also called \text{phon}. You can use http://newt.phys.unsw.edu.au/jw/hearing.html to find your own curve of equal loudness hearing. This website is a lot of fun a lot of fun.

statement.p: A speaker is blasting sound at frequency 1000\text{ Hz} at a 60\text{ dB} level. The frequency of the sound is changed to 10000\text{ Hz}. What should be the decibel level now in order for the sound to appear to the same loudness level?

solution.p: Reading the diagram in , we find that the contour labeled 60\text{ dB} goes at 10000\text{ Hz} corresponds to about 70\text{ dB} of intensity. Therefore, you would need to have 70\text{ dB} of intensity to sound same loudness as 60\text{ dB} of intensity at 1000\text{ Hz}.

exercise.title: Displacement and Pressure Amplitudes from Intensity of Sound

statement.p: To barely hear a 2000\text{ Hz} sound, you need intensity at about -5\text{ dB}. Suppose the density of air at room temperature and pressure is approximately 1.225\text{ kg/m}^3 and speed of sound is 343\text{ m/s}.

(a) (i) What is the amplitude of the displacement of particles in the displacement wave? (ii) Compare this distance to the Bohr radius of a hydrogen atom, which is 5.29\times 10^{−11}\text{ m}, by finding the ratio of displacement to the Bohr radius. (iii) Based on this, what you say about the sensitivity of the human hearing system?

(b) (i) Suppose the bulk modulus of air is B=142\text{ kPa}, what is the amplitude of the pressure wave? (ii) Compare this to the atmospheric pressure, which is around 1.1\times 10^{5}\text{ Pa} by finding the ratio of the pressure amplitude and atmospheric pressure.

hint.p: (a) First get intensity in \text{W/m}^2 and then use the formula of intensity in terms of D_0. (b) Use the relation between D_0 and P_0.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) (i) Note that intensity is given in a relative intensity form. So, first we cnvert the intensity into \text{W/m}^2.
I \amp = I_0\times 10^{\beta/10} \amp = 10^{-12}\text{ W/m}^2\times 10^{-5/10} = 10^{-11.5}\text{ W/m}^2.
Now, we use the relation between D_0 and I, and v=\omega/k to get
D_0 \amp = \sqrt{ \frac{2I}{\rho} \frac{1} {v \omega^2} } \amp = \sqrt{ \frac{2\times 10^{-11.5}}{1.225} \frac{1} {343\times 4\pi^2\times 2000^2 } } = 9.76\times 10^{-12}\text{ m}.

(ii) Let us denote Bohr radius by a_0. We notice that
\frac{D_0}{a_0} = \frac{9.76\times 10^{-12}\text{ m}}{5.29\times 10^{−11}\text{ m}} = 0.18.
(iii) This shows that human hearing system is highly sensitive and can detect displacments even smaller than atomic size.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) (i) We use relation P_0 = k B D_0 = v B D_0/(2\pi f) to get P_0.
P_0 = \frac{343 \times 142\times 10^3 \times 9.76\times 10^{-12} }{ 2\pi\times 2000} = 3.8 \times 10^{-8}\text{ Pa}.
(ii) Comparing this to atmospheric pressure we get
\frac{P_0}{P_\text{atm}} = 3.45\times 10^{-13}.
